text:
I have never made my own pizza crust before, but we decided to try this the other night.  My bf is NOT a fan of home-made pizza and always prefers order-in.  Well....... I doubled it in my stand mixer with the dough hook, and added some pizza spices.  Then I made a sticky mess when I tried to shape the dough and roll it out.  tip= use a lot of extra flour!    The results were two 12-13 inch pizzas!  We used jarred sauce since I didn't have a ton of time to make sauce.  His came out GrEAT in about 15 minutes, nice and lightly browned.  I didn't know how long mine had been cooking, so I took it out a little too soon and it was still a little doughy in the middle.  The main thing though, is the taste was great, super fluffy crust and the bf RAVED about this crust!!  Looks like we will be making this often!  THANKS!!!!

This crust was AMAZING, even my hubby loved it and he is super picky about his crust!  I've made 4 pizzas in 3 days, it's that good!  I forgot to add in the oil, and put in 1/2 cup whole wheat flour in place of the white.  I let it rise for 5-10 minutes then pre-baked it for about 7 minutes before adding the toppings.  Since many others said it the crust was a bit bland I did put some italian seasoning and garlic powder into the pizza sauce just in case.  I can't wait to mass make and freeze these for nights when we don't have a lot of time to cook!

userID:
1682699
Display Name:
Christine A
isPro:

followersCount:
2

96
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family and I make pizza about every week or 2 and had always used the dough mixes (in a pouch) --- not any more! This is simple, and even though it takes a little bit longer than the pouch kind, it is SO much better!  I'd say it's as good as a pizzeria.  Since we make pizza often enough, I bought the yeast in a jar - it's much more economical. I threw it all in my Kitchenaid mixer with the hook attachment and mixed in extras like grated parmesan, Italian spices and garlic powder to give it a bit more flavor.  First time we put them in regular round pizza pans, but this time, just for kicks, we're trying spreading it into half-sheet jelly roll pans to make the pizza bigger and give it a thinner crust.  But don't get me wrong - the regular pizza pan rounds gave us a nice thick, yummy crust that was oh so delicious.  I like to bake my crusts for about 5-7 minutes first without toppings, then take out and decorate and put back in til the cheese is just golden on the edges. If you try this pizza dough recipe, you won't want store bought mixes or ready-made crusts ever again!

text:
This will be our go-to recipe for pizza crust from now on, replacing store-bought frozen and home-made recipes. I was attracted to this recipe because I've had many failures with pizza crust before- this was quick, easy, AND delicious! Added Penzey's pasta sprinkle to the mix but otherwise made as is. For those who like to buy the jars of yeast (instead of the packets), use 2 1/4 tsp. Yumm!

text:
excellent recipie, turned out just like pizza hut pizza crust!!! YUM, alhtough it was messy but very well worth the effort. I just found a little problem with dough being slightly oversticky and hard to roll out, so i just place the whole dough into the pan and 'punched' dough flat. it turned out great, dont even worry about sides being too thick, it will just become the nice and fluffy!!! thanks for uploading:) will use this whenever i bake pizza. However it u are someone who like crispy and hard crust, this is not something you should try.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe. It's so simple & quick. I'll never make pizza dough in the bread machine again. I used fast rising bread machine yeast as this was all I had, I mixed it with the dry ingredients, added the wet ingredients and beat it with the dough hooks on my electric beater for a couple of minutes. I let it rest 15 minutes to allow the quick rise yeast to activate. As others suggested, I baked the crust for 7 minutes before putting the toppings on. This worked great, except I didn't prick the first crust with a fork and it rose up like a balloon, I poked the next one a few times and it worked out much better. This crust is also great with non-traditional toppings such as Alfredo sauce and chicken, or brushed with garlic & herb olive oil and topped with vegies.

Thank you Amanda!!! I have always wanted to make pizza at home, but never attempted to because the dough was just too much work! Well, now that I have two small children, I am so thrilled to have this recipe and be able to make personal size pizzas with them without spending tons of time on kneading etc. I use my stand mixer with dough hook and find it to be soooo easy and DELICIOUS!! (I cook mine at 400 degrees F for 20 minutes and that seems to work out perfect for me). Every time I make it it comes out better and better (now that I have figured out how to work with the yeast)and the kids love making their own pizza! text:
This was my first homemade pizza crust.  I had a new pizza stone with limited ingredients on hand, and I thought it still turned out well. I used all-purpose flour and vegetable oil.  If using all purpose flour, you will need to have a WELL floured surface to roll out the dough.  Make sure to use plenty of corn meal if transferring the crust from a pizza peel onto a preheated pizza stone.  I will probably pick up bread flour and olive oil and make again.  A definite keeper!

country:
None
text:
I've tried other recipes, but this is the favorite in my house!  It was chewy without being overly thick, and was easy to shape.  This dough would also make awesome breadsticks!  After topping the dough I brushed olive oil around the edges and sprinkled garlic powder around.  I used a preheated pizza stone, and went ahead and topped the pizza on the stone.  The bottom of the crust was already starting to crisp before it was in the oven.  It think this helped with the overall end product.

city:

country:
None
text:
Amanda, this is a fantastic recipe! I've made this too many times to count anymore and it always turns out wonderfully. This is our favorite "fast" crust. I do let my yeast foam for 15 min. and then let the dough sit for 10-15 as well, depending on the time I have available. It is STILL much faster than traditional doughs which take over an hour of rise time alone. I cook this on a perforated pizza pan on the bottom rack for a nice crisp crust. I can get 1 thick crust pizza or two 12" thin crusts from this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I found this recipe because I was looking for something quick and easy that I had all the ingredients for.  I had to use a package of yeast that was about a month and a half past its "rises faster before" date, but it still rose OK and tasted great.  When I got to the part where I mix the flour and salt and oil in I used garlic salt instead of regular salt and I added some basil and oregano for an herbed pizza crust.  Then I mixed it with my hands and let it rise for about 45 minutes while I prepared my other ingredients for my pizza.  I also preheated the crust by itself before I added the other ingredients since that is what my pizza recipe called for and it turned out delicious!  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Awesome!  I started making a mental list of all my friends to send this to even before I was finished baking it.  Completely workable dough.  It rolls great,; no stickiness whatsoever. Flips onto pizza stone pretty as you please.  I rolled a little bigger than pan size and placed cheese around the edges and rolled them inward for a 'stuffed crust'.  Also added Italian spices to rolled out crust for a truly Italian crust. This one is definitely a keeper.  No more pre-baked crusts for me!

country:
None
text:
Found this last minute and it was so easy and fast to do. I bought the jarred yeast and followed the tip from another review. I did make the dough first and left it at the side to rise. But only while I cut up the toppings. The longer you leave it to raise the easier the dough was to stretch. I used 100% pure olive oil. Using different types like “extra virgin” will give you a different taste. It was delicious and will be our usual family recipe for pizza.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick, easy, and delicious.  I've made pizza dough many times before, but this was my first time making this recipe and it is definitely going to be my new go to.  I followed the recipe exactly and used my Kitchenaid to mix and knead the dough.  I was impressed by how fluffy the dough was underneath the crunchy exterior considering how fast it had risen.  I only baked my pizza for 15 minutes at 450 and it turned out perfect.  There aren't any extra spices in the dough recipe and I probably wouldn't add any as they could slow down the rising process.  We added extra seasoning to our tomato sauce to compensate and loved the final flavor.

text:
This is pretty much the exact same recipe I use for dough that needs to rise, except I use all purpose flour. It's my go to recipe! I think people who are having troubles arent as experienced with pizza making... if you are having troubles make sure you are kneading the dough until very smooth (I use my stand mixer) and put your pan or stone in the oven to get hot before preparing the pizza on it. Make sure your oven is  very hot. If you have the time you could let this dough rise.

text:
Love the recipe,  only thing I  do differently is since I don't want my crust too dry (by rolling with flour or cornmeal)  is I  pour a tablespoon of olive oil in the sheet pan and spread it by hand. Coating both my palms with oil, I take my rested dough and knead it out on the pan instead of rolling.  It's just a personal preference.

Display Name:
pooklette

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become our favorite pizza dough.  The dough is a little wetter than I'm used to, but I resist the urge to add flour and it turns out great...crispy on the very bottom,  chewy in the middle. 

I just press the dough into a 14" circle on parchment paper, add toppings, and then transfer the paper and all to a preheated baking stone. By the time the top is lightly browned, the dough is cooked through. The dough rises slightly while I'm preparing the toppings, resulting in a hand tossed type of crust...not thick, not thin, but somewhere in between.

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I teach middle school FCS (primarily cooking), and have made this recipe hundreds of times with 13 year olds during our very short 40 minute class periods. It comes out perfect every time!

We don't have enough time during class to allow the dough to rise at all, and it still comes out great. We also never need to bake it for more than 10 minutes.

You can also make freezer pizzas with this dough. Par bake the dry crust for about 3-4 minutes, let cool, add toppings, flash freeze, then wrap and store! Cook like a normal frozen pizza (at 450 until lightly golden).

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Followed recipe, but added to flour 1/4 tsp salt plus a dash, 1/2 + tsp garlic powder, oregano, and basil. I also took reviewer A.S.G.'s advice and preheated oven to 450° per instructions, then put in dough on my round cast iron pizza pan on bottom rack and upped the temp to 500° for 5 min, then returned oven to 450° while adding sauce and toppings, then put back in oven on bottom rack. baked for 12 min. I used All Purpose Flour. We really liked this crust. It's my new go to pizza crust, and maybe also some bread sticks. Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Followed the recipe as written,  the only thing I did was allow the dough to rest for about 15 minutes after mixing.  The dough was very easy to stretch, and held its shape without constantly needing to re-stretch.  I doubled the recipe and made two portions of dough.  After topping the dough, I baked them on a preheated pizza stone at 500 degrees, the dough had a good rise, the crust was crispy.  Excellent for a last minute option for dinner, the wife and kids gave it thumbs up!

Followed recipe except I added some garlic and parsley to dough. LOVED it. Was crisp on the outside and "fluffy" inside. My 7 year olds LOVED it too. All kids love pizza, but not all devour the crusts like they did! I will definitely use this recipe next time.

I used a little more flour than called for. Just enough so the dough is not sticky. I used a pizza stone as well. Since my stone isn't very large this made enough for two medium pizzas. Turned out great!!

I think if you made this and put it in a bread tin it would make great (& easy) sandwich bread. text:
Gosh, was this the best!  I doubled the recipe (for an expected crowd of people) and let the dough rest for, oh, about an hour.  It rose beautifully.  Then I punched it down and let it rest for another 15 minutes.  I don't know why, but I just wasn't in a big hurry. Then I halved the dough and rolled out one half the length of an oblong pan (lightly oiled and added in corn meal).  To be naughty, I lightly brushed some olive oil with garlic powder on the top of the crust and then added the marinara sauce, mozzarella, pepperoni and some basil.  Wowsa!  It is an outstanding recipe and a keeper for me.  Seriously.

text:
I absolutely LOVE this recipe! I found a great idea too. If you use  bread machine yeast you throw everything dry together, including the dry yeast. Mix together and add WARM water. I put everything in my mixer. It takes about 2 minutes or so mix it, then I leave it for the 5 minutes, as the recipe calls for, and then complete the process. I saute my vegetables while it is sitting. The hardest thing for me is pressing the dough into the pan.This has meant that I can make pizza once a week if I want. It is soooo easy. Thank you Chef Rider.

userID:
4298704
Display Name:
WNC Mom
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
144
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I worked at pizza joints all thru college, and know my way around pizza from scratch.  For a quick pizza you can’t beat this!  The texture is excellent; crisp (but not crunchy hard) crust with tender-chewy center. It IS lacking in the depth of flavor that you get from an overnight dough so it wouldn’t hurt to supplement a bit of flavor in there as others have suggested although I did not and I was still quite satisfied. What I DID do:  substituted instant yeast for active dry in equal measure (I found I was able to get a decent rise and more spreadable/stretchable dough after letting it rest for maybe 30 min while I prepped toppings); doubled the recipe; used bread flour and baked on a pizza stone as suggested (but I upped the temp to 400).  Also, I have a hard time with red sauce at this stage in life (over 40) so I used an olive oil base - homemade pesto would be fantastic but I was out. I spread it with olive oil and sprinkled Parmesan on the edge for a Parmesan crust (garlic powder would have been good too) and mozzarella in the center. Then sprinkled Italian herb mix on top and added toppings.  This was a great quickie crust recipe to help sooth the craving for a decent hand tossed crust without the $20 sticker shock of local craft pizza shops.  I will add this to favorites and make it again and again.
Review:

5

I make this pizza crust recipe all the time and it never fails. I use a perforated pizza pan and it browns the bottom like a gas oven (almost). This recipe makes a large pizza.  I used to manage a pizza restaurant so I'm a tad picky. 
The title suits this recipe!

text:
I hate working with yeast, but I gave this a try anyway. It was SO easy. My two year old helped me make it. It's nice and chewy, and the flavor is good but not amazing-- probably a dough that had a rise to it would be better tasting. However, if you're a yeast-hater like I am and still want to make your own pizza dough, this recipe is a great one!

country:
None
text:
I make this recipe every week for movie night. It is just perfect for us. I double the recipe and always throw in a few extra seasonings (savory, garlic powder, onion powder, oregano, etc...depending on what I have on hand). I read a previous comment that suggested pre-cooking it for 5 minutes before adding sauce and toppings, so I do that as well. I put the crusts in the oven and crank the heat to 500 while it's in for 5 mintues. Take it out, put heat back down to 450, sauce and top pizzas and back in for 10-15 minutes to finish it op. Seriously. This is quick. Easy. Tasty. Adaptable. Thanks so much!

country:

text:
This crust is fantastic! Made a couple adjustments based on what we had on hand. We used all purpose flour and melted room temperature butter in place of the bread flour and oil. I buttered the crust and put garlic powder on it before it went in the oven and again about 5 minutes before it came out because the exposed crust seemed dry and hard. When it was done (took 20 mins) the crust was so delish! We doubled the recipe and got two 12 inch hand tossed pizzas. Will 100% used as a staple. Thank you so much!

I did it! My first pizza. I have avoided it for years, eating only whole grains, thick crunch breads. I made this recipe cut in half because I am one person not eight! The dough was VERY sticky so I added more flour while stirring it. Otherwise it would have remained goohy paste on my hands. I baked it in a metal pastry pan for at least 30 min and it turned out nice. Thick, a bit heavy not crusty but OK. What can I do to make the dough better - lighter and fluffier like a french bread with a crisp crust?

text:
I have three teenagers at home and we live in an extremely rural area.  No delivery is available to out home and carryout is nearly an hour each direction. As I became less and less intimidated by yeast recipes I realized there is almost no need to buy things like pizza curst when it can be made so easily at home. This recipe rocks! It is easy and when laid on a Pampered Chef pizza stone creates a strong thin crust, crisp on both sides. BTW, if anyone is interested this recipe x2.5 makes four large pies....the exact dimension of the PC stone. my goal is to make 20 crusts when no one is home and actually get some into the freezer!

text:
I have been using this recipe for years now, and am actually just now reviewing it (sorry!). Over the years, I have discovered that you can take this to the next level by adding garlic powder and oregano to the dough as you add the flour. And then brush the crust with (garlic?) butter right after you pull it from the oven. It takes this wonderful recipe to the next level with minimal extra effort/ingredients. It's a go to easy dinner around here!

This dough is super delicious! If you do have some time to spare, knead the dough for a couple of minutes, then portion out if you need to, set on your work area, place plastic over it, and let it rest/prove. Even just 10-15min of proving makes the dough a lot easier to work with as the gluten has relaxed and delicious.

text:
This is so easy and so good.   I couldn't resist kneading and letting it rise for a short time.   Maybe that's why it made a very thick (but good) crust.  For me, this will be 2 thinner pizza crusts in the future.  I will be making this again.  BTW, I  used 1 cup whole wheat bread flour and 1.5 cups whole wheat pastry flour.  I have always had bad luck with whole wheat pizza crust recipes but this was excellent even though it was not even written as a whole wheat recipe.

text:
I've used this a few times for a quick pizza dough and it's turned out well every time. I really recommend adding your own spices for flavor as you're mixing the dough (or your pizza will be a tad on the bland side. I use garlic powder, oregano, a touch of cumin or tumeric, but really whatever flavors you prefer will mix in well), but as a baseline, this recipe works great!

text:
It's a home run recipe. Easy and excellent results.

I let the dough rise for an hour which created the thicker chewy crust. 

Egg wash for color but I didn't hear the timer and it baked a couple extra minutes as you can see by the "deeper" color of the crust and cheese.

It's half shrimp/dairy-free and half chicken. Plus garlic, onion, and banana pepper.

text:
Very tasty dough!  I took this recipe and divided the dough into two balls. I put one in the fridge for later (just my hubby and I) and rolled the other thin (stretched to fit a 12" pan) . I cooked this at 500f and it cooked up crispy and beautiful.  My only complaint is this recipe is a little on the tough side.   I also added a tiny bit more salt to the dough mix and it tasted way better.  All in all it made a good pizza!

I made no changes to this great recipe. Have made it several times now. I like rolling out the dough as I get it much more even and no holes. text:
When we made this I added about a teaspoon of garlic and herb seasoning, and I made it a stuffed crust using shredded mozzarella. It turned out wonderful, we baked it at 450 for 5 minutes before adding the toppings and we ran butter along the edge of the stuffed crust (I couldn't tell it was there so that is probably a waste of time) then we put it back in the oven for 12-15 minutes, took it out and let it cool for 5, and it was great. Really awesome easy recipe.

text:
This is delicious! I make it every time I am in pinch, and it tastes delicious. A great sauce is just Hunt's tomato sauce with a teaspoon of garlic powder, with some shredded mozzarella and cheddar cheese to top it off. One thing that I should mention, however, and that you have to use a spiky roller and go over your pizza in order for it not to rise to much and become a bread. You can also roll in your favorite cheese stick into the outside edge for a delicious stuffed crust!

text:
I made this recipe as listed, and it is good in a pinch. Docked a star because it is a bit dense.

I tried it again and subbed a cup of unfed sourdough starter for 1/2 C each of flour and water, with only 1 tsp yeast (proofed with 1tsp sugar and 1/4 C water) and it poofed like Neapolitan pizza dough!!! So credit is due for a great starting point for a Napoli style dough.

text:
My son and I made this dough for our "Pizza Dumplings"
We made 14 flat rounds of dough,  pressed each  into  an oiled muffin cup,
added sauce, pepperoni, sliced tomato, black olives & cheese, then pulled the dough over top the filling, pinched the tops closed and baked at 450*  for 15 minutes.
They turned out AMAZING!
Each one was thoroughly baked which surprised me, as we really filled them full!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good basic recipe for pizza crust and you can also use it to make a loaf of French bread or focaccia bread.  It does need more salt, I used 1 1/2 tsp of salt. (and it only needs 1 tsp of yeast, too.  I didn't have a full packet and it worked out fine)  If you can afford the time, knead the dough for 5 minutes and let it rise for half an hour.  Better yet..make it at night before bed and let it rest overnight in the refrigerator in an oiled, large plastic zip lock bag,  It'll be ready to roll out and finish when you are.

Eric Hupf (tkoalas)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5418238.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, at first, I thought this took FOREVER. I used an automatic mixer with dough hooks. This past time, I used a wooden spoon to mix it together. Start with just a cup of flour, mix it all up (until smooth), and then add the rest. It will look weird, but then take it out and knead it by hand. You will be left with a dough ball. Also, make sure you use water at 110 degrees and NOT the typical lukewarm water-on-wrist trick. Yes, use a thermometer if you must. I also added spices to it once I was needing it and then baked the crust a little. It was pretty thin, and next time I hope to let it sit longer to see how that affects it.

5

Display Name:
Matt Latsha

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So far, I've made this twice, and this first time, it was a disaster.  I think it was because I didn't add the sugar to the yeast and water.  Also, the crust was way too thick, so it tasted like pizza stuff on top of bread.  It didn't work at all, and I was kind of ashamed of serving it to my kids.

The second time, though, I remembered the sugar, and also cut the flour down to just 2 cups.  It made for a smaller pizza, but it wasn't three times as thick as it should be.  Next time, I'll probably try 2.5 cups again, and see if the larger pizza.

Something else I did, and I don't know if it had any affect, is put a bowl of water in the oven with the pizza to make it crispier.  It was good, but I don't know if it had any affect.

Finally before I put in in the oven, I drizzled some garlic infused olive oil over the top.  Again, I don't know if it added anything, but it didn't hurt.

If you follow the instructions, this makes a great pizza dough.

text:
This is my go to recipe for pizza dough.  It is almost foolproof.  Everyone that we make pizza for loves my crust.  I like to put seasons in the crust itself. especially if I am using a red sauce.  With a red sauce I usually put Italian seasoning in the crust and with a white sauce I like to add garlic and sometimes butter into the sauce.  Flavoring the crust  just elevates the pizza to a whole new level.  If I am doing a breakfast pizza I coat the crust with a garlic, butter, and onion spread and then sprinkle it with a little bit of salt and pepper.  You can't keep the crowd away .

text:
This is our go to pizza crust recipe. It does work well in a pinch if you don't want to wait that long. However, if you have a stand mixer and kneed it for 10 minutes and let it rise for 1+ hours it yealds a super soft dough with that crunch/strech just like take out. we've also made it, let it rise and then stick it in the refrigerator till you need it. The longer it sits (up to 2 days) the better it gets. So quick method or long you can't go wrong ??

text:
I put the water, yeast, and sugar in my stand mixer and let that sit for about 5 minutes and then added the flour and salt.  Using the dough hook, I mixed on a low setting for an additional 5-6 minutes until it all came together.  Depending on the flour, humidity, and other little variations you may need to add a teaspoon or so of water.  A little water goes a long way.

text:
Made in my stand mixer.  Excellent!  Only thing i changed was adding some dried basil, garlic powder and red pepper flakes prior to mixing.  I did let it rise a little longer ( approx. 20 minutes) .  Dough was not sticky.  Easy to use.   Dusted counter with a little flour and used a rolling pin to shape into a thin crust.  Awesome and super tasty!   Love this recipe, have used it many times.  I use KIng Arthurs unbleached Bread flour.  I always pre-bake crust 7 minutes and then add sauce, toppings and continue bake for another 10 minutes.  Also, i drizzle olive oil on my pizza pans and spray them with cooking spray to insure a crispy, done crust.  Dont forget to use the cooking spray on the outer crust and season it with parm or garlic powder!!! Yum!

Display Name:
artrep

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/889896.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a change in the cooking directions from a recipe I found in a magazine that sounded interesting and it turned out great. I thought I’d share it here in case anyone would like to try it with this wonderful dough recipe. I used this dough recipe.                                                   Preheat oven to 500F. Prepare a cookie sheet by lightly dusting with flour. I rolled out the dough on a lightly floured board then transferred to a oiled sheet of foil. Topped the dough with sauce, toppings etc. Placed the foil and pizza on the bottom, yes the bottom of the oven, NOT the bottom rack, the actual bottom. Cook for about 2 minutes until the bottom is crisp. Transfer the foil to the prepared cookie sheet (floured cookie sheet) and bake in middle of oven for 8-10 minutes more until crust is golden and cheese is bubbly. Let cool and slice.         Hope you enjoy.
Review:

5

text:
I add a couple of tablespoons of sugar to the water as the yeast proofs, it makes the crust brown nicely.  I add 1/4 cup of olive oil to the baking pan to help crisp up the crust....works very think or thinker well.  this crust recipie will make a full jelly roll pan and a good sized calzone if rolled out well.  Makes good garlic cheese sticks if you add garlic butter and cheese.  For really easy cleanup, parchmenct paper in the pan and remove it to a rack right out of the oven helps to keep it crisp...

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe all the time, I suggest that when you mix your warm water and yeast you let is sit for about five minutes with the sugar this gives it a head start and wakes it up.  Also the best flour for Pizza is "00" which has a finer milling and results in a much better crust IMO. Also I'd appreciate it if all recipies would add the conversion for yeast 2-1/4 tsp= .25 oz right at the top, as I scratch my head every time on this one.

I still consider myself a novice in the kitchen and this was my introduction to making pizza.  It really was quick and easy and I've made it many times since.  It's also something I can actually make after work and not just on weekends because of time.

text:
Well named. Worked well for last minute crust. Because of the five minute 'rest time', the texture was a little grainy, more so when eating the bit of leftovers.  Also, the flavor can't have fully developed fully without giving the yeast time to produce what only time with yeast can accomplish. That said, I am keeping this recipe.  Will use it in a pinch and be glad to do so.

text:
My go-to crust recipe is a little more involved and takes significantly longer to slow-rise.  I was looking for a more simple dough that would still be good for a "make your own pizza" station at my daughter's slumber party.  This definitely worked beautifully!  It also doesn't have to be used immediately, I allowed some of the dough to rise for about an hour and it was great too.  Silky smooth and easy to work with.

text:
I will definitely make this again!  It's quick, easy and foolproof!  Doesn't have tons of flavor as is, so I will take a cue from others probably try butter instead of oil next time!  I brushed some oil on a 9x13 glass dish and sprinkled some corn meal on there. Pressed the dough into the bottom with slightly raised edges. Baked for 10 mins., removed from the oven and added toppings...then baked on the bottom rack for another 20 minutes or so. Yum!

userID:
3587241
Display Name:
Denise Rowell
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my second time making this recipe and we love it!  The first time I followed the recipe exactly and my family loved the flavor, but the crust was a little thicker than we like.  (When I tried to roll it out, it was really spongy and difficult to thin out.)

This time, I split it into two balls to make two pizzas.  The first one was just the right thickness, but still a little difficult to roll out because of the sponginess.  With the thinner crust, 15 minutes was too long to bake.  The cheese burned on top (but the pizza was still delicious).  

For the second one, my son tried tossing the dough into the air, and it landed in my sink full of soapy water!  :-)  While the first pizza was cooking, I mixed up another batch of dough (because it really is "quick and easy").  We divided the dough into two balls and baked the second pizza for 10 minutes.  The toppings were perfect, but the crust was a little under cooked.

We rolled out the dough for the third pizza, but since we weren’t going to eat it tonight, we left it sitting on the dough board while we ate (about 30 minutes).  It was so much easier to work with after it sat out for a little while.   The sponginess was completely gone and it was a breeze to roll out to the size of my pizza pan.

This is definitely quick and easy and delicious!
Review:

userID:
4992331
Display Name:
hmeservy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum. Make exactly as described but serve as appetizer breadsticks and a pie. Divide dough roughly in half. Dump the small half onto a floured surface as the rest rests in the bowl. Roll into a circle.  Brush on melted butter, sprinkle with garlic salt, basil and oregano. Grate on a healthy layer of Parmesan Romano and bake roughly 12 minutes. While that bakes, prepare the remaining dough as pie with desired toppings. Bake roughly 11 minutes or until crust is brown and cheese is bubbly.

Next time try pre-baking the pizza only about 5 minutes before topping and baking the remaining time.
Review:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading through the comments, I followed a suggestion to roll the dough onto a pan, turn the oven to 500, put the dough in for 4 minutes (original comment said 5, but that made it too crisp), then turn the oven back down to 450. Then I poke the dough all over with a fork to let the air pockets out, top with marinara sauce, parsley, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, basil (just to give it some extra flavor since the dough is a little bland), Parmesan cheese, mozzarella, pepperoni, and Italian sausage. It only takes 13 minutes to cook after that, and that makes it a little well done. My husband LOVES this recipe. We make it almost twice a week.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is good, but it does need rising time for the best taste. I made it twice and gave it 90 minutes each time, rolled it out and let it sit for another 30 while I got my toppings ready. That worked out nicely. I will say this though, the first time I used "00" pizza flour. It came out great, like a hand-tossed, but not thin crust. The second time I used actual "bread flour" and it was more like bread. I did it on a stone both time, so the bread dough one had more of a crisp artisan crust, bread-like interior, etc. I can't say I am as much of a fan of the "bread" version.  Things to keep in mind.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
What an easy perfect pizza dough recipe! The ONLY addition I made was  a tsp or so of Italian herbs to the olive oil before I poured the oil into the flour mixture.  I did knead the dough by hand for probably 10 minutes  -until the dough developed a smoothness and cohesiveness.  I used the recipe this time to make  pizzas  in two muffin tins.  Absolutely delicious!  The filling was hamburger, Italian sausage, and grated pepperoni; and the pizza sauce I made from canned Italian crushed tomatoes, green bell peppers, onions, garlic. I filled each cup and then dotted the tops with pieces of mozzarella cheese; and then into 425 degree oven for 10 minutes   Pizza crust was AWESOME as was the mini pizzas.  Can't wait to make a full size pizza with this dough recipe.

text:
It was very tasty.  I doubled the batch and added a tablespoon of  seasonindry Italiangs and a teaspoon of garlic powder.  This would be tasty for a white sauce veggie pizza, but it over powered our pepperoni and ground beef with onion pizza.  The recipe is great as is.  I recommend this recipe for anyone who is just learning to cook.  One tip on yeast though, be very careful about the temperature of the water.  If it's too warm, it kills the yeast and it won't rise.  Have fun, and experiment.

text:
I doubled the ingredients except the yeast ( used 1 Tbs yeast.)  I weighed the flour, 22.5 oz. A double batch made 6 personal pizzas (about 8-10 inches in diameter). I rolled the dough thin and baked for 10-12 minutes at 450F. Turned out great, will make again. 
5/30/2017 Made this again. Increase bake time to 12-15 minutes. I also let the dough rise for 30 minutes. I think it was better.

I doubled this recipe and it made 2 pizzas and some breadsticks, enough to feed five hungry people.  The only thing I added to the recipe was 2 tsp. Italian seasoning and I used garlic infused olive oil. I used my kitchen aide with the dough hook to mix the dough until all the flour was incorporated and I did let it rest for about 15 minutes. It was the easiest pizza dough recipe and it was amazing. This will become the pizza dough recipe we use from now on.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick and easy!  Just as the name suggests, I was able to make this crust up fairly quick.  I used all-purpose flour.  I also, as suggested, added seasonings/herbs (oregano, garlic and onion powder).  I topped with a Mexican blend cheese (only cheese on hand) and pepperoni. The pizza kid only ate one slice (maybe due to the cheese).  I, on the other hand, ate three slices.  I thought it was pretty good. However, I did note it was more bread-like than crust-like.  Even with the additions, the crust still lacked the traditional pizzeria flavor.  I do plan to make this again, possibly dividing the dough for 2 pizzas, increasing the resting time and adding butter.  Oh, and using mozzarella next time! ??

None
text:
It's so easy! I have a family of 6 and have been procrastinating making homemade crust because time is crucial. I am interrupted every 5 minutes because someone needs me. I love you don't have to wait for it to rise. It's quick and easy and I can make it without thinking too far ahead. I'm not a great planner so this is perfect for me. I've made it 3 times now, and it's never failed. It is easy to spice up the crust for those of you that need more taste (my husband) but it's perfect for the kids and I who like to keep things simple. Keep it towards the bottom of the oven because the cheese will burn if you bake it in the middle or top. But truly this is the best thing ever for my family!! Thanks for posting this!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
While I don't usually like to rate recipes if I've made significant changes to them, I hope my comments may be useful to others. I added 2 tsp of Italian seasoning and 1 tsp of garlic powder to the dough. I ended up needing a bit more flour than called for. I let my dough sit for a half hour before rolling it out on a mixture of flour and corn meal. I spread out some light Alfredo sauce on the crust and baked it for five minutes, then added shredded cheese and shrimp. The crust never got quite as "crusty" as I would hope, and I believe this might be because I made it too thick. I used a 13" perforated pizza pan, and even with over 30 minutes in the oven, the crust didn't seem quite done. We ate it anyway and thought it was delicious, though, so it didn't matter ultimately.

I love this recipe, it's really easy.

This was an easy and quick recipe.  I like that we could eat in less than an hour! 
I didn't have bread flour or enough white flour, so I used 1 1/2 c. white flour and 1 c. wheat flour plus 3 t. baking power and a little extra salt.  I also just used wheat flour for dusting and rolling out the dough. 
It turned out great!

This came out great, even better than many of the no-knead dough recipes I've tried.  It works just fine with AP flour if that's all you have on hand. As some other commenters suggested, I gave it a 30 min rise in a covered bowl before baking it, which I would recommend as well. In fact, I'd probably give it a second rise too after stretching it out into the pan.

text:
Simply marvelous! I made this and it blows away the pizza I've had in Virginia. I moved from New York so I'm a pizza snob but this is amazing! Add parsely, oregano and onion powder to the dough when you are adding the flour because it adds some flavor. I also recommend folding the dough around the edge and pinching it to make a thicker crust. I used the back of a spoon to spread some olive oil around the crust and put garlic salt on the crust. absolutely  amazing.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the following changes and had PERFECT personal pizzas for 4.

To crust:
Add 1 tsp each onion and garlic powder before kneading. Let rise 30 minutes before rolling out dough; divide into 4 balls and roll each really thin (love a cracker-like crust). Brush tops of each crust with olive oil. Pre-bake crusts on lowest ove for 5 minutes @ 500°.

To prepare pizza:
Turn oven down to 450° .  Place each pizza onto the top of a turned over baking/cookie sheet or pizza stone. Add sauce and ingredients. Bake about 7minutes, and slide pizza off pan, directly onto rack (this gives you the cracker crust) for another 5-7 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
very forgiving...this came out great even though i screwed up. i forgot to add the olive oil at the proper time. after i mixed it up, i set it aside to rest a little and discovered that i missed the oil. i threw it in and kneaded it by hand, then let it rest again, about 10 more minutes. other changes, then i rolled it into a rectangle to fit my baking pan and let it rest again, about 30 min. added sauce, cheese and sliced mushrooms and popped into 450 degree toaster oven. after 10 min i turned it down to 425 and cooked 10 more min. it developed a nice thick, "deep dish" style crust.  great taste and texture.

I of coarse changed the bread flour to 1 1/2 cups unbleached Wheat flour and 1 cup unbleached flour.   I kept everything else the same.  It turned out fantastic!   Thank you for the recipe!

text:
This was an amazingly easy recipe to follow. I read some of the other reviews and added some Italian seasoning and garlic powder. I left the dough rise about 30 minutes and prebaked it for 5 minutes at 500 degrees before I added my sauce and toppings. I then reduced the oven to 450 and baked the pizza for about 15 minutes. It was better than some I've had from local pizza shops. I'll be making it often when I get hungry for pizza.
Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This recipe is absolutely perfect. I made it last night and it was a huge hit. I tried 3 different recipes  before and none turned out as great as this one. I also made it by hand, kneading for about 5 minutes and sprinkling flour on the dough every once in a while to get to the right consistency. I did let the dough rise for 2 to 3 hours which is the only change I have made. Didn't even have to use a rolling pin to shape it, 17 minutes in the oven and we had a perfectly cooked and crispy pizza. My fiance absolutely loved it and I was told Pizza Hut and other restaurants and brands can't make pizza as well as I do. This is the easiest crust recipe I have ever made and by far the best.

text:
This is my go-to pizza crust; it's easy and doesn't require raising time.  However, cooked according to the instructions here, it comes out soggy.  I made one simple adjustment:  I parbake the crust for ten minutes before putting on toppings.  I mix in some garlic powder and Italian herbs, then add a mixture of Parmesan, Romano, and Asiago cheeses right before baking.

text:
From 9000 feet altitude: Super easy, simple, and good.  I made one batch straight from the mixer to the oven and it was great.  Another I made in the morning, let rise, punched down, then put in the fridge until I was ready to use it.  Both made an easy, delicious pizza crust as thick or thin.  I had to add a bit of flour, just to keep it from sticking in the mixer.  Maybe a quarter cup at the standard recipe.

text:
I've used this recipe a few times  because it's pretty easy and basic. It is pretty bland though so I either add more seasoning to the dough or brush it with olive oil and garlic powder. It's not necessary to use bread flour, I never have and it turns out great. 
Also, if you seperate into four portions and let this rise at least 30 mins you can bake it at 425 for about 25 mins and it makes a great basic French bread mini loaf! Can also freeze the raw dough. Very versatile recipe.

This was super easy, delicious crust. I actually made the crust in the oven for 12 min them took it out, added Nutella and march mellows, then put it in for 1 min regular oven then 2 min Broil. OH MY GOD:) Enjoy if you make this crust with a twist.
Note: (Nutella in the oven for too long is not good, so make sure your crust is almost or fully done before you add these toppings)

None
text:
Buttered a cookie sheet and sprinkled cornflour. Enough dough for a good sized rectangular rustic style pizza. Lightly patted olive oil around edges for crisping. Sprinkled salt, garlic, and Parmesan cheese on dough after ladling sauce. Baked for 30 minutes at 425 degrees. Rolled out thin and came out crisp. It's a bread crust and not flaky so you might need extra sauce but that's not a bad thing. Very easy and will do again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I came on this site to find a quick Bisquick like pizza crust, when I came across this recipe and decided to give it a try. I was running late and needed a quick crust for breakfast pizza. We usually use jays crust found on this website and my family loves it. I just throw it in the bread maker and roll it our when it is ready. 

 I was disappointed in this crust. 1st there was no way to "stir until smooth". I had to fold in the flour by hand and this took a very long time! So much for fast! I still did not manage to incorporate the whole 2 1/2 cups (I probably got in more like 2c). 2nd, I expected this recipe to make about 1 large pizza, I was wrong again. I made a small ball of dough which probably would have been sufficient for a med. pizza. I have a large family with three growing boys, we really needed a large pizza crust. Not having time to make another I went ahead and tried to press the pizza dough out to fit my pizza pan. After much taring (and swearing) I almost gave up, but I persevered! I put it in oven to pre cook a bit...it barely rose..it was pretty flat (yes my yeast is good, I made bread 2 days ago with it) but everyone was hungry so we dug in and ate it anyway.

 Taste wise this was ok...it was not what I expected, based on the description. It was not at all soft and chewy. We found it rather thin and very crispy and , but I had never had this issue with jays crust. If you have time go for a

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/909398.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this crust tonight and followed it exactly (although I eyeballed the olive oil, I'm a heavy pourer so there may have been an extra tablespoon of olive oil)asside from bake time. I baked it at 400 F for 20 minutes, I use a nonstick dark pan prone to burning whatever I bake on it, so I lower the temp. Regardless, I think 20 minutes at 450 would over bake the crust. This is the best no rise pizza crust I have ever tried. Heck, this is one of the best crusts I've made rise or no rise! I don't think it needed any seasoning, unless you like that specifically, which I do not. I do think it is essential to use bread flour, you can expect a good crust with all purpose, but don't expect it to come out as good as if you used bread flour.

country:
None
text:
This is 5 stars...IF you let the dough sit for 30 or so minutes.  It came out very soft.  My daughter says it's the best crust ever.

This is 2 or 3 stars...IF you let the dough sit for only 5 minutes. When baked it was like a hard biscuit instead of a soft pizza crust.

As others have said, make sure you add your own seasoning to the dough.  I traded out the 2 TBS of olive oil for 1 TBS olive oil and 1 TBS of butter (then mixed the seasoning in the mixture).  It turned out pretty good.  Next time I may skip the olive oil and just replace it with butter.  We'll see.

Added Italian seasoning based on previous reviews. I split this into two thin crusts. Tossed a pinch of cornmeal in the bottom of my 12" cast iron skillet and baked it on the grill for 12 minutes (crust bottom was golden brown). I have baked this at least half a dozen times on the grill and it is wonderful every time. I use a volcano grill,with cover, 20 briquettes, but it would work on a gas grill just fine. Plus, there is enough heat left for a cobbler on the grill while enjoying the pizza!

13217712
Display Name:
mellowde
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This very close to the recipe I developed over 30 years of trial and error trying everything possible to change ingredients and technique in the process.  Mine comes real close but as you all may or may not know flour moisture content requires adjustments from day to day to produce consistently good results.  On a humid day flour may be much heavier with water in it.  Arid climate will produce lighter weight flour to volume ratios.  Making dough is an art form and one perfected by experience over time.  Large commercial producers use test equipment to not only monitor flour moisture content but use weight ratios to produce their dough/crust in a consistent manner.  I would simply recommend you add less flour up front and then add little quantities, kneading well between additions to get to the proper texture.  Knowing what the proper texture is the artform.  For instance, knowing that by kneading very sticky dough for a longer time will produce dough that isn't as sticky without adding anything.  The molecular structure of the dough changes over time (what some call resting the dough).  What happens is the strands of gluten bond with the water and other ingredients while it sits.  So many times folks ask me why when they use my recipe their dough is too sticky to handle.  Well it's because they don't have enough experience to understand that more kneading and resting is necessary.  How much you say?  That is the art.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-03-17T09:38:23.58
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
15478858
Display Name:
brookebroccoli
isPro:
False

Love the ease and simplicity of this recipe. It is one that doesn't take a huge amount of time or fancy ingredients. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1898998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this enough, especially with adding the herbs to the crust.  I am admitting that this is the first time I've used a pizza stone, and I was looking for a nice, easy dough recipe.  This definitely was nice and easy.  A little sticky, so I needed to use a little more flour when turning it out.  Again, I'm still getting used to my stone and exactly where I want to put it in my oven.  The crust cooked well when I stuck it in the first five minutes.  Didn't stick to the stone at all.  Then, I put toppings on and put it back in the oven. Took a little longer than I thought for the pizza to finish, and the crust still felt a bit play-do like.  It tasted fine, but it was incredibly heavy and just felt like it wasn't "done."  I will definitely chalk most of this up to beginner's error, but I think I'll be experimenting with other doughs as well.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
14792651
Display Name:
Susan T
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Maybe being from Chicago I have higher standards for my pizza lol! But this crust, just like any other I've tried to make myself, is nowhere near pizzeria quality. I didn't alter the ingredients but did let it rise for at least an hour, as some said rising helped it. I used a pizza stone as some suggested as well. I baked it five minutes on its own at 450. It puffed up like a dutch baby even though I had pricked it several times before putting it in the oven. Once I flattened it, I added the rest of the ingredients. I would have preferred using a pan because I don't find it easy to take it in and out of the oven off the stone so was standing there in the heat adding ingredients! The crust was way too thick for one pizza yet didn't seem to be enough to divide in half.  I cooked it 17 minutes total which was at least two minutes too long using a stone. It was kind of hard and brown plus chewy. As others said it was bland even though I added olive oil and spices to the top after rolling it out.  The two good things I will say about is that it can be made faster than crusts that need to rise (maybe my mistake was letting it rise longer) and that it wasn't soggy at the bottom like most homemade crusts I've tried. Though a variation of this would work in a pinch, I will be sticking with store bought pizzas for a while! These homemade pizzas take far too long and aren't good enough for all the effort involved ... In my opinion!

userID:
3097476
Display Name:
Sarah
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9

madeRecipesCount:
90
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/166172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this with the "Exquisite Pizza Sauce" found here on Allrecipes and it made a great combination! I just did a basic pepperoni and mozzarella pizza.

I used 1-1/2 tsp of instant yeast instead of 1 packet of active dry, but proofed it the same anyways just because I like to test if the yeast is still good before adding to the whole recipe. 

Other than that I didn't change anything and it was great. 

The only issue I had was it was a little bit rubbery? I'm not sure if it was the pan I used though. I would really like to try this one on a pizza stone rather than a non-stick pizza pan (with holes).  But I'll have to buy one of those first. lol ;)

I will have to check out the other reviews to see if anyone else had that issue. But even if I can't figure out why it's doing that it was still very good. It seemed less rubbery as it cooled too so maybe I just ate it too fast. :)

A definite keeper for us! I love that it's SUPER easy and fast, and doesn't require a bunch of rises to make. Just perfect for making a quick pizza!

Next time I try this I will also try to brush it with a butter-garlic mixture for a little oomph of flavor. Without it is still good, but it sounds like it'd be even better with that. Will update review on how it turns out. :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars for flavor and texture and a 5th star for ease of preparation and the fact that I always have these ingredients on hand. We've used this for pizza crust several times and last night I used it for breadsticks - added 2 minced cloves of garlic, rolled the dough into logs, brushed the tops with butter and sprinkled with parmesan. Baked at 450 for probably 20 minutes until the tops started to brown. Next time I'd let them rise a smidge before baking for a lighter breadstick, but they were still great!

Edit 5/24/25: I consistently use at least 3 cups of flour for this dough now, and it gives it the right consistency (smooth and elastic, not too sticky).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW, what a great rising pizza crust. We used rapid rising yeast instead of active dry yeast and added the yeast to the dry ingredients first like you should with rapid rising yeast and then refrigerated it after letting it sit for 5 minutes to activate. When we decided to use it a couple hours later we took it out of the fridge rolled it out with a little bit of flour and cooked it on a pizza wheel. We used a little less sauce than usual to keep it from becoming soggy. This is the best crust I have made from home yet and will continue using this recipe. Must try for a rising pizza crust from home.

So far, this is the best pizza crust recipe I've tried! I made it with hard white spring wheat flour (to be healthier) and added about 2 tsp of gluten so that it would rise like normal bread flour. text:
I made this pizza crust recipe because I was in a hurry.  I didn't expect much. It was delicious. I always do a quick pre-bake with my homemade crusts before I add any toppings. I pre-baked this crust for 5 minutes then put on the toppings, returned to the oven for 15 minutes. It turned out great. If you want you could always do a traditional first rise, punch down, and then form your crust. This recipe is a keeper.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would re-title this recipe "Deadly Pizza Crust". This is just too good! I followed the recipe exactly besides for the part where it says let rest 5 minutes. I let it rise for 30 minutes in a bowl covered with a towel for a fluffier texture. I made two versions. For the first version I made golf size balls and flattened it with my fingers, brushed on some oil, arranged sliced olives-saute'ed onion-tiny strips of pickled sweet red peppers on top, and sprinkled some coarse salt over it. For the second version I added garlic powder to the dough, made finger sized logs, and brushed a mixture of chopped garlic-oil-paprika-onion powder-garlic powder-salt on top. What can I say? Heavenly stuff! My advice to you first timers? Double the recipe right away. There's no way you can just eat one:)

I was having a few families over and thought it would be fun to make homemade pizzas. I bought all kinds if toppings but forgot to buy dough for the crust! In a pinch I tried this recipe! I was not sure if it was going to turn out because I didn't have enough all purpose flour so I used half cake flour and I had expired yeast! It was so fast to make! No kneading required! It turned out great! Everyone thought it was delicious! I'm sure it is healthier without all the chemicals pre made dough from the store has! I will be saving money from now on and make this recipe instead of buying pre made dough!

text:
I have made this recipe now for a while and I really like it. I like to make the rise time after mixing 30 minutes. then I roll or press into a buttered pan then cover with wax paper. then turn the oven on warm when oven is warm turn the oven off then set pan with dough covered with wax paper in the oven. then I let the dough rise again another 30-45 minutes. iv found that this way gives me the best most fluffy crust ever. other than the change up in preparation I love this recipe.

text:
We loved this recipe! Very easy to throw together for a quick meal. Per other posts I added: 
1. 2 1/4 tsp. is .25 pkg. of yeast  
2. Added 1/2 tsp. of basil & oregano 1/4 tsp. onion powder to oil for crust
3. Brushed the edges of the crust with garlic powder mixed in oil
We found that there was too much dough for our regular sized pizza pan, so we took out 1/4 of the crust.

text:
This is as advertised...quick and easy. Also tasty, and versatile as listed in previous reviews!  No longer buying pizza mixes.   Divide dough in half and freeze for future.  Thaw in frig or on counter. Have made it and found letting it rise for an hour will make dough soft and full.  Press down on cookie sheet, spread lightly with pizza sauce and prebake for 5-8 minutes produces a crispy bottom crust but top is moist and chewy.  My only pizza crust recipe.  Now my whole family makes this.

userID:
11633248
Display Name:
Fatima
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1073776.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pizza crust is WONDERFULL!  I have made it many times since I first found it.  I use all purpose flour and let it rise for 10 to 20 minutes depending on how busy I am. besides pizza, I have used this crust for calzones, cheese filled crust, bread, and even deep dish pizza. The crust can be made to be chewy or crispy according to how thickly you roll it out. I love this especially because the other one I used took about 1-2 hours (or even overnight) to rise, and I would have to plan it about a day in advance so that it would have enough time. With this one however, I have a pizza ready and cooked in 40 minutes max. I don't think it turns out as fluffy or chewy if you only let it rise for 5 minutes by the way. If you are doubling or tripling the recipe (like I always do) then I recommend cutting it into about 4 balls before letting it rise so that it will be done sooner.  I haven't tried adding herbs or anything else to the dough, so I'll try that next. :)
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-12-06T17:54:51.99
helpfulCount:

text:
Wow turned out great! I let the yeast sit in the water for about 10 - 15 minutes and after I mixed in the other ingredients I let that sit for about 15 - 20 minutes. I did kneed this a little and then rolled into a ball. I put a 1/2 tsp water and 1/2 tsp oil around the ball while it was sitting for the 15 - 20 minutes. I usually use a store bought crust that is inexpensive but makes a thin crust. We like that, but now have this recipe that is even cheaper, .30 - .45 cents, and it makes a thick pizza crust for when we want a thicker crust! Plus just totally yummy! Thanks great recipe :)

text:
Loved this recipe!  I took this a step farther and when stretching it out on my pizza pan, I made sure it was extra thick on the edges.  I then took 4 pieces of string cheese, cut in half, and placed them all around the edges, folding over the extra crust and pinching it shut to seal it in.  VOILA...Stuffed crust!  The family loved it!  I will absolutely use this recipe again!

text:
So glad I found this recipe. I was going to make my usual bread-machine pizza dough, but ended up being away from the house for hours and didn't have enough time to make it that way. My brother still wanted pizza, so I did a search to see if there was any pizza crust I could make in a hurry. I came across this recipe, and with all the good reviews, I figured I would give it a try. I'm so glad I did. It was SUPER simple to make. I love the fact that you can add your toppings and bake it all at the same time...unlike my bread-machine recipe that requires pre-baking the crust for 20 minutes before adding toppings. The crust turned out great. Not only did it look amazing, but it tasted great too. It was nice and browned around the edges and on the bottom, but still nice and soft on the inside. My mom said it tasted better than pizzas you buy! My whole family loved it. I doubled the recipe and made two large pizzas. Now we will be able to have left-overs. :) I would definitely recommend this recipe. It's my new go-to recipe for pizza crust. Easy and delicious. What more could you ask for?

text:
I made this two days ago and gave the recipe three stars. I now suspect something was wrong with the yeast I had previously used, cause I Tried it again last night and I HAD to do over that review. WOW! was i wrong the first time! It came out PERFECT! Probably the best pizza I ever ate! Both my husband and I were in awe with every bite and had to fight not to wolf it down. I took it up a notch by adding 5 large cloves of minced garlic, 1 tablespoon of honey and 2 tablespoons of oregano to the fermented yeast mixture just before i added the flour. I ended up with more dough than i needed so i put the rest in the fridge and i plan to turn them into cheesy sticks or something tonight. My extra touches resulted in heavenly yumminess! The texture was sooooo perfect. Better than any pizza i had ever bought. I will NEVER buy pizza again! Thank you for this recipe!!!

We were trying to think of some different meals for our extremely picky kids and decided to try a pizza bar.  After finding this recipe for the dough we gave it a try.  It was a huge huge hit with everybody including the parents.  The dough is ready in minutes and the 30min given is accurate given the baking time required.  We did the kids pizzas a little thicker and ours a little thinner and both came out great, not too doughy and not too crisp.My favorite thing is the price, compared to buying a pre-made Boboli crust, this is a fraction of the price and just as good and is fun to make with the kids.  We will definitely be putting this into our regular rotation.  Thanks so much.

text:
I made this tonight because I forgot to buy pizza dough at the grocery. It definitely is quick, came together well. I just made plain pepperoni and baked it at 500 for 15 minutes (what I usually do with store-bought). It seems a little underdone on the crust front, though the cheese and 'roni are great. I would stick to the 15-20 minutes at 450 direction, maybe this would cook the crust better while not letting the toppings get too burnt. Definitely tasted soft & doughy, but again I cooked at a higher temperature for 15 minutes.

Our family really loved this recipe. I've made other doughs that require along rising/proofing time, but this recipe makes no false promises. It's a great dough made quickly. I live in the Southeastern US and it's quite humid, so I usually need to add extra flour to make a workable dough. I just add 1/8 cup or so until it's a good texture. Also, I sometimes add honey instead of sugar.

text:
Very Good and really easy!!! I have made many different pizza crusts all which have failed and to be blunt, I am a really good cook but then again my standards are really high... Most crusts have a "yeasty" taste, but not this one. It was great! Follow recipe completely. Also make sure your water is 110... if its higher it will kill the yeast and if its lower it will not activate it. Use a meat thermometer to check. :) Thanks for the awesome recipe!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3287652.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This works!  I made a double batch and (of course) failed to read the details, so I put all the ingredients except flower into the bowl and then let it sit for the 10 minutes.  I think the sugar and yeast in the warm water worked even better than the yeast alone, because after adding the flour (and a little more to get the right consistency as I kneeded it) it really did it's thing.  Within one hour (the time it took to get the stuff out for making the individual pizzas) we ended up having enough pizza dough for 8 10" pizzas.  Nice thin crusts that rose just a little while cooking.  Just like in Italy.  Perfect.  

TIP - since the individual pizza were for the kids to decorate, we precooked the pizza crusts for about 4-5 minutes before toping them.

text:
I am a novice at bread making, and don't own a bread machine, so tend to seek out recipes like these. This recipe should be in everyone's rotation, it's incredibly easy, there's no major time waiting on the dough to rise and the crust comes out beautifully. Even someone as new to bread as me found this easy (and yummy) to follow. Would definately recommend. If you're just making one 12 inch pizza, I'd recommend using half the dough and freezing the other half for another day. My first pizza was um, VERY deep dish, lol, it really only needed half the amount (note to self: press thin into pan, crust will rise significantly while baking :) )

text:
Not a huge fan.  I think the crust would have been better if it cooked alone for 5-10 minutes, then add sauce and toppings and bake a little longer, 'til cheese melts and toppings heat up.  As written my pizza came out with really dark brown cheese, and doughy crust.  The second pizza came out with cheese overdone and crust underdone as well, even though I reduced the bake time by 5 minutes.  I think I'll look for another crust recipe, which is a disappointment, since I like the "quick and easy" part.

text:
This is the first review I have ever left but felt it had to be said. I have tried many pizza dough recipes and this was the best thus far.. I doubled the recipe added 1 tbs of Italian seasoning and 1/2 tsp of garlic powder to the dough. let it rise about 10 min and let the kids make their own personal pizzas.. I did precook the dough for 8 min at 470 degrees before adding the sauce and toppings then returned for 15min at 420 degrees. The crust was soft and flavorful! Will make again!!

text:
Great recipe for tasty and quick pizza.  I use bread machine yeast so I don't have to proof it and all purpose flour since I don't ever have bread flour.  I split the dough into 3 pieces, roll them out to 16" circles and put on the toppings.  I also sprinkle italian seasoning on the dough before I spread on the sauce.  I like to use my grill to cook these pizzas at 550 degrees, so they are done in half the time and taste great!

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I put the first 3 ingredients in my Cuisinart without the blade, and then drop the dough blade after a few minutes, then add the rest of the ingredients and pulse until it comes together.  Let it rest for 5 and knead 'till I get a windowpane.  I oil a half-sheet pan and press the dough out .  It is a cross between Sicilian and Chicago style .  This also makes a great bread stick.  Roll out to a square, lay strips on a parchment covered sheet pan, brush with garlic parsley butter and herbs, a sprinkle of garlic then parm and mozz.  Yummy.  This is a fantastic dough of you like chewy crusts.  Thanks for the recipe.  Needs no planning. I can throw this together quicker than ordering a $20 pie...it costs me less than frozen and tastes fantastic!

None
text:
This is the basic recipe for pizza dough! When I first tried it I felt duped. This is foccacia bread I said! Well, yeah. Same recipe!
The second time I left it rise, then used a bigger sheet pan, and it was--the typical chewy somewhat strechy pizza dough you'd call hand tossed.
That's what great about this recipe. You can make it in the time it takes to chop up the veggies, or wait for the rise time. Either way it's the recipe I'll always use. Better homemade pizza than take out anyday!
And yes, like every bread recipe the amount of flour is going to vary. Add herbs and garlic if you feel it's too "bland", like, pizza dough is!

text:
I have tried many many pizza crust recipes, this has been the best so far, both in ease and time. After reading the reviews, I dissolved the sugar and yeast in 1/2 cup warm water, and saved the other 1/2 cup warm water for the final mix. I used 2 1/4 c. stoneground flour (it's heavier), and the recipe still came out great. I made a garlic spinach and mushroom parmesan pizza and my husband loved it. Thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
This is a great recipe & very easy to make.  I sometimes add wheat bran or use wheat flour for some of the regular flour.  You can add granulated garlic or whatever herbs or spices to suit your tastes.  Like many others, I let the dough rise a bit.  When ready to roll out I just put in on an oiled cookie sheet & spread it out with my fingers.  As far as toppings are concerned, I just go with whatever I have around the house.  I really like using a pesto sauce that I pick up at Costco instead of a tomato sauce.  Play around & put whatever you like on this crust the sky's the limit.

text:
I like this recipe. It is quick and easy. I have also used Tyler Florence's on foodnetwork, but it takes all day and I will only make it on a weekend b/c of the time. So, with that said, this tends to be my go to dough. However, the first time I made it, it was a little too bready for us. My husband is a east coast italian guy, no chicago style in our house and even hand tossed in most restaurants doesn't fly around here, so we split this recipe in half and make two light pizzas out of it. I suppose I give it a little time to rise as I'm cutting up toppings and making sauce too, that might help it, I'm not sure entirely. I cook at 500 deg for about 5 min and comes out great.

text:
Love this crust! Super easy to make, I just toss it all into the food processor and let it go until it’s a dough ball. It did come out very sticky and loose, so I added flour (all purpose) until it was more workable. No need to let it rise. My only complaint is that I am a messy cook and flour gets everywhere, but that’s not the pizza's fault. Been using a cookie sheet as a pizza pan and it comes out great. I also like to spray some olive oil on the pan and the crust. Helps it crisp up and easier to get out of the pan.

text:
I am giving this recipe 5 stars because it delivers what it says...quick and easy! I have to start by saying that this was my first time ever making a homemade pizza. Although I feel pretty confident in the kitchen, making a pizza sort of intimidated me. This recipe changed that! This recipe produced a perfect, thin and crispy crust for my pizza. For those who think that the crust lacks some flavor, I think this can be fixed by experimenting with a pinch of this and that. I brushed the crust with olive oil once it was in the pan, then I pricked it all over with a fork because I think my mother-in-law does that, and then I sprinkled italian seasoning all over it. I can now make homemade pizza anytime...So happy I tried this!

text:
This is a very versatile recipe, and very good also. We use it regularly on Beer and Pizza Friday. Sometimes I make it as written and sometimes tweak it, depends on what kind of pizza we decide to make. It always turns out great. If you need or want ideas to change it up a bit just read some of the reviews, so many people have some great ideas, or just go crazy and start adding stuff. So far I have never used a mixer I just mix it by hand and cook it on an old pizza pan I stole from my parents 25+ years ago and it came from a pizzeria that went out of business so it must be at least 35 years old I don't grease it, corn meal it, or flour it and the crust does not stick. In our oven 475 seems to be the right temp.

text:
I've made this a few times and it always turns out great! After trying the original, I've found we like it best with 1 tsp of Italian seasoning and 2-4 Tbsp of Parmasan cheese mixed in for some added flavour. 
I just tried it with whole wheat flour tonight and used 1 3/4 cups whole wheat and 3/4 cup of all purpose. It was a little chewier. If you're used to whole wheat variations of things this would probably be fine. If you like a really crisp crust, it might be a little much for your taste so you might only want 1 or 1 1/2 cups of the whole wheat.

text:
My husband and I loved this pizza crust ! It was very easy and quick. When I rolled the dough out it was way too big for my pizza stone and I had one heck of a time transferring it from my cutting board to my stone. I would recommend cutting the dough in half and making smaller pizzas. I would also recommend using parchment paper, I used it under my second pizza worked like a charm !! Just for those who might not know, wax paper isn't the same as parchment paper !      

I will be making this again !!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dough really IS quick and easy! I made mine with all purpose flour, then with bread flour, then with whole wheat flour, then with whole wheat bread flour--it turned out beautifully each time! I added a teensy bit extra water and olive oil when using the regular whole wheat flour, just because the variety I use can be quite dry, but otherwise, I didn't change a thing about the recipe; each time, the dough came together into a soft but not unmanageable ball. I'll admit, I cheat on the "handmade" part by mixing up my dough in my stand mixer, but I have a feeling that the dough would come together just as nicely when kneaded by hand. I like to make a batch (or double-batch) of the dough, and then divide it into smaller portions, setting aside one to use right away and wrapping and freezing the rest. I thaw a portion of dough overnight in the refrigerator, let it hang out on the counter or in a warm place for about an hour before baking, and then stretch out, top, and bake. Delicious, simple, fast = GREAT. Thank you for this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here's a quick pizza dough for those days when you don't have a lot of time after work.  I made this with the BBQ Pulled Pork Pizza recipe on this site, and the combination was superb!  Sometimes, when I eat pizza, I eat the crust extra fast, because it is not good, but this crust is great!  After reading reviews, I suggest adding basil, oregano, parsley, & onion powder to the olive oil before adding to the dough.  Also, let the dough rise in a warm dark place for a 1/2 hr (if you have the time), and spread a mix of olive oil and garlic powder along the outer crust for extra flavor.  Also, I used a pizza stone, which always helps pizza cook evenly.

userID:
8892255
Display Name:
Susan White
isPro:

followersCount:
7

0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2100711.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is exactly as the title suggests: quick & easy! I've been using it now for almost a year and we've developed our own pizza, made the way we like it ~ better than takeout any day!! I add 3 generous teaspoons of dried minced garlic and 4 generous teaspoons of dried minced onions to the crust for a super savory crust. By using lard on our pizza dish, the crust comes out crispy on the bottom and yet, soft and chewy. We top it with about 2 cups of shredded mozzarella, 2 cups of shredded Monterrey jack, 1/2 cup grated fresh Parmesan cheese, fresh tomatoes (seeded and chopped), oven broiled mushroom slices (to extract the juices), and whatever other toppings strike our fancy on that day. The result is a fresh-tasting pizza everyone loves and asks for the recipe. Many thanks, Chef Rider, for this great recipe!

text:
This recipe was a dinner saver for me tonight.  I had purchased refrigerated pizza dough from the deli case and accidentally glued it to my waxed paper!  I had recently bought yeast at Sam's, and had everything but the bread flour so I used all purpose.  Went together great (thanks to other reviewer Robyn for letting me know how much yeast to use!), made a thicker crust than I normally like, but it tasted great and cooked up in exactly 15 minutes topped with my Buffalo chicken pizza toppings!  In case you want to know those, blue cheese dressing as the sauce, diced chicken sprinkled with dry ranch dressing and sauteed in butter then mixed with wing sauce; crumbled blue cheese and tons of mozzarella (oh, some of the mozzarella goes onto the dressing first!)  Will do again since I have 2 pounds of yeast!
