text:
a good base, i tripled it, we have a lot of kids, mostly boys and they all like things different. i went ahead and added a little more salt, just a pinch, and a good 1 and 1/2 tsp. of italian seasoning.it made it really yummy, and the smell while it baked was making our mouths water! i lightly kneaded the dough, put it into a oiled bowl (olive oil) covered it w/ plastic wrap and let it sit maybe 10 minutes or so, divided it. i placed it on a lightly oiled baking sheet with corn meal scattered on it, and it spread nicely, no holes! that's one for the books for me!! and it was great. i prebaked the crusts until they were just starting to brown, sauced them, cheesed them and topped them how the kids like and cooked them for another 10 to 20 minutes, depending on the pan. it was great.

region:

country:
None
text:
This pizza dough was great! My dad used to spend 2-3 hours making homemade dough! This only took about 15 minutes to make! It was so delicious that it was hard to stop eating it! The crust came out light and bread like, quite soft. It was not too dry and chewy like some crusts. It is better to let it rise for a few minutes in a warm oven though. But not a problem...I simply prepared the other ingredients while my dough rose. I used to work at Mountain Mikes Pizza for several years and this dough recipe is just as good or even BETTER than theirs! This dough is certainly easier to work with. This dough isn't so "springy" and keeps it's shape well which makes it a lot easier to form. I will definitely keep this recipe handy for many years to come! We really enjoyed having it for Christmas dinner!

text:
I'd give it 3.5 stars. This was a good pizza dough for dinner in a hurry. My kids loved it, but I didn't "love" it, the texture reminded me of a homemade buttermilk biscuit...
I'll keep this recipe for future use when I'm in a hurry to make dinner and don't have much time.
If you have one of those counter top rotating pizza ovens, this really isn't the best dough for that since it rises A LOT! It would be fine for an oven or a larger than 12 inch dough.

text:
Who wants to wait an hour for dough to rise on a weeknight?!  This is a PHENOMENAL recipe. I don't keep bread flour on hand & the recipe works just fine with regular flour. I've used the dough with red sauce, white sauce...just about everything.  As one reviewer suggested, use half the amount of water with the yeast and then add the second half while mixing..seems to fine tune the consistency of the finished crust. Since initially trying this recipe about 3 weeks ago, I've gone to it 4 times since! You won't be disappointed.

text:
I make this in my food processor. Blend the dry ingredients, proof the yeast in the warm water and sugar, stir in the olive oil and drizzle into the running machine until it forms a ball. I form the crust on a sheet of parchment paper right on my pizza peel, then when it's all ready, I slide paper and all onto my pizza stone and just wait for the brown, gooey goodness that IS homemake pizza! I've also added a few dried herbs into the dry ingredients for a different take, basil and oregano are naturals!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow. Best crust ever. I've made other recipes from this site and others. You would think using the longer recipes that require you to rest and let rise, punch it down etc. would be a better option, but i not even necessary. I made some adjustments bad on trial and error. I used a thicker pizza pan lightly sprayed with oil.  I used 1Tbsp only of garlic oil, instead of 2T . I think its important to really have yeast that has about an inch of foam on top, be patient and have fresh packet. I poked it with a fork and at 325 in my oven, it worked perfectly. After about 20 minutes, it was browned lightly with amazingly even baked fluffy crust.
 My favorite is 1T softened butter and 1 1/2 T garlic bread seasoning spread over the crust. ( don't use too much!) Fresh diced tomatoes, and fresh mozzarella , sprinkled with basil and black pepper before and after baking.

Display Name:
ashgaruz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Substituted half of the bread flour for whole wheat (I actually substituted in a little wheat germ too, but my crust was a tad more biscuity than my ultimate preference, and I'm thinking that's why). Also substituted garlic salt for salt. Kindof forgot the olive oil altogether. I added dried Italian spices and a little carraway, too. The flavor was magnificent...and so aromatic!!!
On the pizza itself I mostly used ingredients in my kitchen that really needed to be cooked up or eaten soon: 5 or six cloves of chopped garlic, onion, very ripe tomatoes, the greens leftover from my radishes, kalamata olive spread, fresh basil from the garden, fried and chopped up bacon pieces and bleu cheese scattered all over the top with what was left of my tiny bit of parmesan. Overall, the pizza was FABULOUS!!! I only give the crust four stars because it looked a little plain without the substitutes (though it was a great, basic recipe to doctor up).

text:
I let mine rise up both times I made it.  What I love about this is that it is no-knead so it really is very easy.  Just let the yeast sit in the water than throw in the other ingredients and stir.  Its good to know that if you don't have time you can use it right away instead of letting it rise.  Put enough oil in the pan, sprinkle with corn meal and let it rise twice and it tastes just like pizza hut crust.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the greatest thing. Not so much because it tastes good (really it's kind of bland... I can see why other posters have suggested added herbs or spices to it). What I love about it is how quick and easy it is! There's no planning ahead involved!  You want pizza? You can have a hot pizza ready in under an hour.  I've never had a whole lot of luck with yeast breads but this is so easy, I can't believe you don't have to let it rise and knead it. It's very easy to work with, a little sticky but a small handful of flour makes it very easy to stretch in the pan. I find the recipe makes a very thick crust, but I prefer thin.  The recipe as stated easily makes two 12 inch pizzas with thinner crust (though I usually do mine in a very large rectangular pan). So easy and way better than any of the "instant pizza crusts" available at the store! Thanks for the recipe!

Display Name:
sahm2nick

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3056.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good crust, although a tad sticky each time I've made it.  I just dump the ingredients in my bread machine, and let it do all the mixing/kneading for me, then turn the machine off before the rise part of the cycle (since the recipe only calls for 5 minutes of rest time).  I always need to add a bit more flour in the kneading cycle, but no big deal.  We love this for our grilled pizza on the BBQ - leave it on a lightly greased pizza pan, place on grill over indirect medium coals, cover, and leave alone for a few minutes.  When it starts to bubble on top and firm up, I flip it off the pan directly onto the grill.  When the first side is golden, I pull it off again, put sauce and toppings on the browned side, then slide it back onto the grill to melt the cheese and brown the other side.  Absolutely to die for!!  I've never seen my kids eat so much pizza, and that says a lot!  LOL!
Review:

Looks great and will definitely remember other people's advice over flavoring the crust or putting some herbs with olive oil before the rest of the toppings:) Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We used to make pizza crust with frozen bread dough, but it's so hard to work with (not to mention a lot of stores don't even sell it!). We tried this recipe a few months ago and it has been wonderful! My husband won't let me go back to the frozen bread dough. It's so pliable and really hard to mess up! You can add all your favorite seasonings. We add garlic powder, oregano, and basil. We also coat the entire crust with garlic powder and olive oil. It's so good! And don't worry about "failing" at the yeast. I've used water that was not warm enough and the dough was fine. I just had to add a little more flour. The consistency was just fine though!

text:
This simple crust went perfectly with the tuna melt pizza I concocted.  It's light enough and crunchy enough.  The crust isn't too dense of too chewy.  My girlfriend raved about this creation.  Only thing I did differently was to  some italian dry spices to my dough.  I allowed the dough to rise about 30 min. then worked dough into pizza form (building up edges for crust.  I baked using a cookie sheet, which worked out just fine.  I applied my topping about 10 min into the baking process.  I topped with basil pesto, perpared tuna salad mixture (to liking) and topped it off with cheddar cheese.  This was a BIG hit for just the 2 of us!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is really good! I've never made a punch/rise dough but I don't feel the need to now. I should note that it makes a very thick doughy crust, which I like but some don't.  I give a hearty second to the suggestion another reviewer made to mix some italian seasoning with the olive oil before adding it to the mix. All-purpose flour works okay but I really think the bread flour is the way to go.

The crust can be a tad dry and the remedy I use is to rub a little olive oil over the crust and, if you're feeling particularly decadent (which I almost always am), sprinkle some parmesan cheese on it too. It adds a fantastic flavorful crisp and makes me glad Boyfriend doesn't like the corners as much!

country:
None
text:
What a delicious time saver.  I followed another reviewer's suggestion to add 1/2 tsp. basil, 1/2 tsp. oregano, and 1/4 tsp. onion powder to the oil before adding it to the crust.  Although I thought that would be too much spice, it was perfect. My dough hook on my mixer mixed it all together perfectly and after letting it rest the 5 minutes, it rolled out beautifully. I also brushed the edge of the crust with olive oil before baking.  Since I had a commitment after rolling out the crust, I covered it and put it into the refrigerator for an hour before adding the toppings.  Worked out great.  Thanks submitter for this great and easy Pizza Crust recipe.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, this recipe was a usable pizza crust.  If you aren't too picky about your flavor and texture and need dough in a pinch, it's workable.  However, when I go to the effort of making pizza, I want it to taste fantastic and this was not it.  Admittedly, I've got very picky taste buds.  I am an experienced cook so I know it wasn't my skill that was lacking in this instance.  I look for my pizza crust to be light and airy but have enough structure to hold up the toppings.  This was more like eating bread dough rolled out under some toppings.  Pizza crust and bread dough aren't supposed to have the same texture and consistency.  I'll keep looking for my perfect recipe.

5

text:
This crust really is quick and easy, and the end product has never been anything less than amazing!! I have made pizza from it, and it also works great for pepperoni bread. (just make the dough as directed, roll it out, top with pepperoni, 8oz mozzarella and italian seasoning, and pop it in the oven at 375 for 40 minutes)  The last time I made this I used the quick rising yeast and let the dough rise for about 40 minutes... it TRIPLED in size and the result was a THICK crust!! WOW!! it was amazing!! From now on I'll be doing it that way.

This was pretty good. I liked the fact that I could make it in a jiffy and without much effort. text:
My husband and I really enjoyed the pizza.  I will add an addtl 1/4 c. bread flour next time as the dough was very sticky.  The middle of the dough was still soft after baking it with all the toppings so I would recommend to do a short prebake or lower the temp of the oven.  The cheese was getting a bit dark so I pulled it out of the oven.  I will definately use this recipe again...........still better than any pizza I've come across in this part of the country and as a New Yorker, I grew up on good pizza!!

Fantastic recipe that I will definitely make again.  However, will use at least 1/4 cu. more flour since I found the dough very sticky.   We like lots of toppings so we needed at least 10 minutes more of baking time to get a crisp crust.  My DH thought we should bake the crust first and then add the toppings and bake for another 15 minutes depending on topping.  We will try that next time!  All said, great taste and recipe will become a standard in my collection.

text:
followed other peoples` instructions and added the following: 1/2 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp oregano, 1/2 tsp onion powder (this goes into olive oil before adding to batter) as well as the garlic powder/olive oil brushed on just before adding toppings. I also let the dough stand about 1/2 hour in the fridge, which was apparently way too long--the bread turned out spongey. But I guess that was my fault! I`ll make it again, but next time I`ll only let it sit for 10-15 min.

text:
Wow, this was really easy and so good!  I've used pre-made crusts before (like Trader Joe's dough) and have had trouble with them cooking all the way through before the toppings burned.  No issue with this one. I let it rise for about 10 minutes while I prepared toppings and grated cheese.  It was REALLY easy to spread the dough to the edges of my pizza pan, and it cooked up perfectly chewy/crisp.  I used pesto sauce, fresh tomatoes, black olives, and mozzarella cheese.  YUMMY!

text:
Excellent flavor for such an easy and quick recipe.  Made into a large crust for our huge cookie sheet.  On the advice of other reviewers: mixed by hand; added 1/2 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp oregano and 1/4 tsp onion powder to the olive oil before mixing into the flour/yeast.  Let rest 15-20 minutes.  Great flavor and cooked up fine in 20 minutes. Thanks for sharing

country:
None
text:
Terrific and tasty crust. I was in the mood for cheese pizza and didn't want to wait for the crust to rise - I also didn't want to clean up a lot of dishes :) So I whipped up this crust following the recipe, but replacing white sugar with brown and adding onion powder, garlic powder and mrs. dash seasoning to taste. Baked on a pizza stone for 15 mins at 400 degrees and the result was a crunchy bottom crust with a surprisingly soft center. It didn't rise as high as Jay's Crust (also on this site) but it came pretty close.

Great recipe! I've never been satisfied with homemade pizza crusts until this recipe.  Like other reviewers I added Italian seasoning and onion powder to the olive oil before mixing in.  I let the dough sit for 20 minutes and brushed with olive oil after rolling out.  I baked the crust for 5 minutes before adding the toppings. Truly quick and easy and a big hit with my family.

text:
My recipe books are all packed since we are moving and I was happy to find on here that is the exact one I have been using for the past 15 years.  Definitely a staple at our house.  I make it first and let it sit for 5 minutes while I get out all the toppings.    It is fabulous to use for grilled pizza, as well.  I also like to make extra so we can grill the left-over dough and eat it with "dipping" oil/seasonings.    This dough is very forgiving and great to add spices to.  You can use it as a great jumping off point for many uses.  Thanks for posting this here!

userID:
3055025
Display Name:
Starlet
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/100877.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was good and SO EASY! But I must've written it down wrong cause I wrote 1TB (not 1TS) of sugar, but it came out great anyway. I used 1/2 brown and 1/2 white sugar with instant yeast and warm water in a bowl til foamy (about 10 mins) added the salt, evoo and ap flour and kneaded by hand maybe 2 mins. We used 2/3 of the dough for 2 personal hawaiian pizzas, topped raw dough and baked apx 17m. The middle was a little soft, but still quite good. Refrigerated the remaining 1/3 dough in a ziploc overnight (kept just fine) and used for a breakfast pizza, this time pre-baked dough 10m and it was perfect. Topped with hollandaise, lightly sauteed onion, red pepper, mushrooms, then scrambled eggs, canadian bacon and cheddar and baked add'l 15m. Sooo good! One thing though, press or roll it really thin, as thin as you can without making holes, or it'd be too bready once baked cause it did rise up a bit in the oven. And definately pre-bake the crust 10m before topping. I actually think this is better than the more time consuming recipe on this site with like 1000+ good reviews!

I really like this recipe. Adding the olive oil to the dough gives it a nice flavor though I doubled the salt to punch it up a bit.   Once I rolled the dough out I also brushed it with more olive oil, and than drizzled a little bit of honey over it before adding the other sauce and toppings. text:
I love this recipe! I know the crust could be better if more time was taken, etc. but in our household we don't have tons of extra time and we really like pizza. To meet the demand for pizza in the past, I've just bought high quality cheese pizzas from the grocery store and topped them myself before baking. This quick and easy recipe allows me to pop a pizza in the oven in no time and make it 100% fresh. I also add whole wheat bread flower to my pizza, so it is way healthier than a regular frozen pizza. Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
The recipe makes crust with a nice texture, AND it is easy to work with and makes a good sized crust. Many recipes I've tried are hard to stretch and don't make quite enough. I agree with another reviewwer that it's a bit bland, but you can add things to it to make with more flavor to suit your family's taste. I also bake the crust at 450 degrees for about 5 minutes BEFORE topping it, then top it and bake about 8-10 minutes more, depending on the toppings.

None
text:
I really loved how easy this crust was to make. I mixed all the ingredients with my hands once it was time to add the flour. My hubby and I put it on a rectangle baking sheet with some flour on the pan, then spread the dough out into a rectangle not completely covering the whole pan but most of it and then we put it in the oven for about 5 mins. It rose a bit high but I flattened it down with a spatula before adding the toppings. We also put some olive oil on the crust. I was worried about it cooking too slow in conjunction with the toppings but it came out PERFECT. I'll be making this again, definitely!

text:
***UPDATE!  This is a never fail crust for me!  I always add 1 tbsp of sugar to it, and always add some Italian Herb seasoning and parm cheese to the flour before mixing.  the longer you let it rise the softer the crust will be.  And I do still prebake the rust before adding the toppings.

This is awesome!  For my first time making this, it turned out beautifully.  I did add an extra 1 1/2 tsp of sugar, but I doubled the recipe.  I also added some parm cheese, and italian seasoning to the crust before baking it.  Out of the doubled recipe I was able to make 2 individual sized pizza for the kids, and 2 cookie sized (a little thinner crusted) pans.  The bigger ones, I baked the crusts for a few minutes before adding the toppings.  A big hit here...will be making it again!!

I've always been afraid of making homemade bread/pizza dough, until I joined this site!

I started out with this before I branched out to something a little more complicated. This was super easy and pretty much foolproof. I used my Kitchen Aid mixer which helped. (I sure am loving that I have an excuse to use it as much as possible!)

I used half for my kids' basic pepperoni
and the other half for a Blue Cheese Appetizer Pizza I found on this site. Both turned out great and I couldn't be happier. I won't spend $2 on Papa Murphy's pre-made dough anymore.

text:
So quick!  The way pizza should be.  I usually use frozen dough from the grocery store, but this came out with a far crisper bottom than that does, even when cooked on our pizza stone.  Also it was great to be able to use whole grains (I used half whole wheat flour, half kamut flour).  Worked out fabulous.  I added about 1/2 t of italian seasoning and about 1/4 c romano to it.  For my taste,  the dough was a tad sweet, so I will add just a bit more salt or cheese next time.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first time I'd ever made a pizza crust from scratch, and it was excellent. I took the advice of some other reviwers and added some spices, let it rise for about 45 minutes, and then brushed it with olive oil before baking. This will be the only recipe I use for pizza crust. I used all purpose flour, and it worked perfectly. One reviewer said s/he ended up with "gooey" batter, but I don't see how that's possible. I initially thought mine might be too dry and was tempted to add a bit of water, but I kneaded it with my hands for about 5 minutes, and it ended up being the *perfect* consistency. I'm wondering if the reviewer who ended up with gooey batter sifted the flour, which would cause him/her to end up with less flour than there should be... Also, mine cooked perfectly done in 15-20 minutes, so I'm not sure how people are ending up with uncooked crust either unless they haven't spread out the dough enough to resemble a pizza. Mine was spread out on my pizza stone to be the size of a large pizza (and it still ended up being a thick crust once it cooked.)

text:
This has become my standby pizza crust - we have homemade pizza every Saturday night, made with this crust.  The bread flour makes a BIG difference in the outcome, so be sure to use it if you can.   I've made it with both bread and AP flours, and the bread flour crust comes out with a texture similar to restaurant pizza.  I usually make it an hour or so ahead and let it rise, but it works just fine without that step.  Very good, very easy.

text:
What a spectacular recipe for pizza dough. I followed the recipe exactly, and man.. what a pizza! As a transplanted New Yorker living in Texas, I've been searching for an acceptable takeout/restaurant pizza here, and it hasn't happened. I will be making this many, many more times.
One note- it's kinda important to mix the sugar with the water, then sprinkle the yeast over the top for an even coating. And if the water is too cool or too warm, it won't activate the yeast.

region:

country:
None
text:
I double the recipe when I make it and freeze half the dough for another day.  I bake it without toppings on top of corn mealed stone for 10 minutes before adding the toppings and baking for another 10 minutes.  From start to finish it takes about an hour.  I also found I need to roll it really thin because it does rise a lot in the over.  So a really thin crust does not come out thin but the normal thickness of pizza.  I also found I needed to knead it for a little longer than suggested.  Not much longer, but until the dough was smooth in texture.

Display Name:
Chloe

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making pizza at home for 13 years-- since I was eleven. I've always been lazy, and made the dough from a mix-- but today, I discovered I was out, starving, and desperately in the mood for pizza! This was the fastest recipe I found. Time was of the essence!
I followed the recipe pretty closely, but I added a small amount of extra flour (I was using all purpose) because the dough was more sticky and thin than I was accustomed to with the mixes (to which I also normally add more flour).  I also added oregano, basil, garlic powder and onion powder to the mix with the flour (I didn't measure, but around 1/4-1/2 of a teaspoon each).  The dough smelled incredible.
I don't pre-spread the dough, just spread in a pre-greased pizza pan.  The dough was still quite sticky, so I put a little olive oil on my hands to spread it, which worked fabulously! 
I used my normal cheese blend and put jalepenoes and turkey pepperoni on top-- it was so good that my parents ate half the pizza, which was supposed to be my work food for tomorrow!  Oh well, a definite, delicious success!  Highly recommend!

I followed the directions exactly except for using all-purpose flour instead of bread flour. The only thing I would do different would be too roll the crust out thinner next time; it rose more than I expected and was a bit too thick.

None
text:
This pizza crust recipe was exactly what I was looking for!  I was craving pizza, and I needed a recipe for a yummy pizza crust, but I didn't want to take hours making it.  I was able to make this home-made pizza crust in just a few minutes.  I followed the recipe exactly as written, allowing it to sit/rise while I prepared my toppings (about 15 minutes).  It tasted way better than any crust I could have purchased at a store.  I made my crust thin, so I froze my leftover dough in the freezer for breadsticks later.  I recommend this recipe to anyone who may be looking for a fresh baked pizza crust, but does not have the time or does not want the complexity in making a traditional pizza crust.  Very nice flavor and texture!
